:wave:  Sorry for the confusion here with uploads. We are trying to simplify the process with the next version of the API.
By having the file in the filemanager do you mean that you don’t want it showing up in the UI?
As for having files not in the public CDN, the correct way would be to upload them with `allowAnonymousAccess` set to false, this would block both indexing and require a signed url to access

And we’re also rethinking the hidden field for the next version of our API. As it stands we’re completely removing access to hidden files, and instead will rethink rolling out a solution based on file ownerships.

1. What we want is something secure first. Our contacts are sending us sensitive documents (birth certificate, proof of citizenship, etc.) through forms. So we don't want that to be on a public CDN
2. We want a way to display these documents in HS records that is more user friendly than links in a property. So we thought that displaying it as an Attachment would be the best.
3. We want to be able to delete the documents once we have used it and we no longer need them. And by delete we mean to disappear from any servers.

For our next api, we’re looking at integrators hiding files from the file dashboard as a bit of an antipattern since users should know what files they have acces in their account. Saying that, the next version of our api will let you upload files that will not be indexed by search engines and will not be accessible without some form of signed url, as these files can easily be GDPR deleted as well so they will be scrubbed from our database and our s3 bucket. Files that have the private property flags set to true (`allowsAnonymousAccess:true`) are only served out of our private cdn that requires a signed url.
Our next api is looking to go into beta near the end of June, so if you would like we can include you and your portals in that beta group.

I ran into this question also... the documentation for de-duplication of contacts does apply when they are loaded via API, but for companies the de-duplication does not apply. I ran into this problem in an application with multiple threads, it was creating duplicate companies with the same domain... in order to work around it, I had to make sure one thread creates a company, and passes the ID to other threads for more processing. A second problem I found, is that the search can claim for many seconds after creation that a record does not exist, due to some kind of race condition in the record indexing. Moral of the story: be really careful when bulk creating records or you can generate a bunch of duplicates.
I have seen odd race conditions where the search does not pick up records for many seconds after they are made, but have not debugged it enough to file a worthwhile support ticket as of yet.
